Story: Organize codebase according to gem conventions
Gem interface should take data structures, not file paths
Description: The code that loads a person set from a file could be moved to a test helper.

Story: Score groups are paired using split-and-shift
Description:
See Phil's notes on penalty function:

It is important to set various priorities at different numerical scales. For example, the most important consideration is to minimize the McMahon score difference between opponents, with the split-and-shift pairing system coming as a later concern. This could be accomplished by defining a penalty function ...

Story: No two people should ever get paired twice
Odd-numbered field results in a forced bye
Description:
If there are an odd number of players remaining in the tournament after awarding all of the voluntary byes, it will not be possible to pair everyone in the field. In this case, one player must receive a forced bye. If the Tournament Director previously identified a “bye volunteer”, this player is awarded a forced bye and is not paired for the round. If no bye volunteer is available, then one will be selected during the pairing process.

The selected player is the one with lowest rating who has not already received a forced bye and who will allow a valid pairing to be created with the remaining players. If no such player exists in the lowest score group, the pairings in successively higher score groups are undone until a bye recipient can be found.

Story: 0.1 Can pair multiple rounds and report winners
Documentation should describe how TDs can remove a volunteer from the player set to avoid forced byes
A player is never assigned a second forced bye
Description: A player is not assigned a second forced bye unless he volunteers for it. A player may ask for any number of voluntary byes, however.

Story: 0.2 Support for byes and other tournament director tomfoolery
A player should not be assigned the same color more than three times in a row
Description: A player should not be assigned the same color more than three times in a row, or for more than 50% of the rounds in a tournament in any case. Some Tournament Directors do not apply this principle, while others allow players to select color by nigiri.

Story: Avoid pairing of players from the same state, city, club, etc.
